text: [Music]
some were taken by the local authorities
for instance in Birmingham when a whole
areas were being cleared or changed
through redevelopments but quite a few
were also taken by private photographers
at the time because photography was new
technology of the age of your life and
people are astonished that you've
capture faces and people at these
moments to say frozen in time and
private photographers often used to go
out and take photographs and then sell
them as postcards as memorabilia for
people living in the area and here are
some kids sitting on the pavement some
of them don't have shoes they're wearing
caps
among the many interesting things that
you get out of these photographs is that
in those days children would dress like
little adults they were indeed you
mentioned that some have no shoes and it
was very common amongst the poorest
people for children to share shoes for
girls to share of bonnets and there's an
another photograph showing shoeshine
boys in Liverpool and again two of those
have no shoes these are signs of abject
poverty which provide I think a
fascinating insight into the lost world
of Victorian England and the challenge
was to select images that conveyed
aspects of the period in the content but
also there the great geographical spread
and also some idea of the astonishing
range of building types right across the
spectrum say from back to back housing
to grand mansions
